Adsorption of U(VI) from sulfate solution using montmorillonite/polyamide and nano-titanium oxide/polyamide nanocomposites
Mohamed F. Cheira a,*, Mohamed N. Kouraim a, Ibrahim H. Zidan a, Wael S. Mohamed b, Taha F. Hassanein c
a Nuclear Materials Authority, P.O. Box 530, Maadi, Cairo, Egypt b Polymers Dept., National Research Centre, Dokki, Giza, Egypt c Chemistry Dept., Faculty of Science, Helwan University, Cairo, Egypt
A R T I C L E I N F O
Editor: Despo Kassinos
Keywords: Montmorillonite Titanium oxide Polyamide Uranium Adsorption
A B S T R A C T
The polyamide-based nanocomposites were formed via inorganic nanosized (montmorillonite clay MMT, or TiO2) particles that incorporated inside a polyamide 6 (PA6) matrix. Moreover, the MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites were prepared by simple dissolution methods. Morphology of the gained nanocomposites was studied by SEM, EDX, TEM, FTIR, and XRD techniques. Batch adsorption was fulfilled to determine the uptake capacities of U(VI) (93.0, 21.0, 134.0, and 125.0 mg/g) on the MMT, PA6, and MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites, respectively from sulfate solution in the pH 4.5, 30 min contact time at room temperature. The adsorption-desorption recycling was indicated that U(VI) adsorption has excellent stability and selectivity after seven cycles by 0.25 M HNO3 eluant. The kinetic data of uranium adsorption on MMT, PA6, and MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites were suited well to a pseudo-second-order mechanism, and the Langmuir isotherm followed the equilibrium adsorption experiments. The tentative mechanism of the adsorption of U(VI) on adsorbents was proposed. Finally, the optimum adsorption conditions for MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites were applied for U(VI) recovery from the El-Sela sulfate leach solution.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Uranium is the principal nuclear fuel, and it is a naturally occurring radioactive and high toxicity element, as well as it has the extensive sources that are devoted to uranium production by mining and processing from its resources [1–3]. In the last era, uranium has globally earned admission as the main energy source. Currently, uranium supplies are to almost 16 % of the electricity production globally. It was determined as the major backbone of energy for the next days while the fossil energy assets wane by the center of this century. Uranium was employed to fuel up extensive than 400 operational atomic reactors in the globe that generated huge quantities of electricity. More generally, uranium mining and processing produced from the increase of permanent resources by improving uranium concentrations in several areas throughout the world [4]. In Egypt, uranium ore materials resources involve conventional and nonconventional sources found at some locations in Sinai, Western Desert, and the Eastern Desert. In recent decades, the Nuclear Materials Authority carried extensive programs
concerning uranium exploration. Those details pointed to the outcome of significant uranium mineralization associated with younger granites into the Eastern Desert. In the ultimate southeastern part, particularly; Halaib environs, uranium mineralization was recently devising at Gabal El Sela [5–8].
Various techniques were performed for U(VI) recovery from stream solutions, for instance, membrane separation [9], ion exchange [10,11], solvent extraction [12,13], chemical precipitation [14] and adsorption techniques [15]. Adsorption technique was selected for uranium separation due to selectivity, simplicity of design, low cost, flexibility, high efficiency, easiness of operation, and broader applicability for dismissal of numerous varieties of pollutants [16]. Several types of adsorbents were used and studied to eliminate uranium ions from leachate and wastewater, like inorganic matters, composites [17], and polymers [18] that have intense adsorption spots and stimulated extensive concern. For instance, the hydrogel comprises multiple proper functional groups (amide, carbonyl), that could act as donors toward interaction to metal ions [19–21]. removal of pollutants from wastewater, because of their huge surface area, surface activity, high adsorption capability, and efficiency. Therefore, nanomaterials have attracted significant attention in the removal of several heavy metals ions from liquid solutions. U(VI) adsorption was discovered the adsorption capability of nano-TiO2 that represented with the BET surface, Freundlich isotherm, and grain size [22]. Montmorillonite has classified as the primary ingredient in the distribution of bentonite block systems. Uranium(VI) adsorption was applied onto montmorillonite in the lack and the presence of different carbonate concentrations [23,24].
Lately, the solid adsorbents were prepared by green synthesis for the selectivity of the metal ions or organic materials extraction against the other impurities present in waste solutions. The Cu0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4, MgFeCrO4, and CoCr2O4, nanoparticles prepared by green synthesis, were employed for the removal or degradation of dyes from aqueous solutions [25–27]. Moreover, green synthesized ZnO, CuO, Mg0.5Ni0.5AlxFe2-xO4, ZnMn2O4, and MgMn2O4 nanoparticles were applied for photocatalytic degradation of different dyes [28–31].
Likewise, the ZnAl2O4@ZnO nanocomposite was used for photodegradation and removal of acid orange 7 dye [32]. Also, the Fe3O4/hydroxyapatite/β-cyclodextrin nanocomposite adsorbent was utilized for the adsorption of some heavy metals from waste solutions [33].
Polymers attached with inorganic nanomaterials had better efficiencies for displacing uranium from its sources, due to their broad surface areas, surface activities, and high adsorption capabilities. Uranium ions were extracted by three polymers that were polyethyleneimine, carboxymethylated polyethyleneimine, and polyacrylic acid [34]. A new polyvinyl alcohol/titanium oxide was manufactured and used for uranium adsorption [35].
Synthetic organic polymers bearing polyfunctional groups (–NH2, OH, COOH, CONH–––2, NHCH––2− PO3− ) in the surface efficiently were adsorbed heavy metals ions from their solutions [36,37]. These polymers have small surface areas and low adsorption rates during the applications as adsorbents. Meanwhile, inorganic nanomaterials like transition metals or metal oxides, MMT nanomaterials, etc., have broad surface areas, and moderate adsorption capacities. Nanomaterials and polymer-based nanomaterials were utilized to remove uranium ions and some heavy metals from waste solutions [38,39]. Polymeric nanocomposites were also used for the formation of inorganic nanoparticles inside a polymer matrix [40].
Polyamide utilized in various application fields, such as electronics, automobiles, consumer goods, and packaging. Polyamide contains amide-type links, materials kind of that could be gained in nature, like silk and wool [41,42]. Although initially -and still- the polyamide was used to produce nylon textile products, today, it is used as injected plastic and is already widely utilized in the plastic industry [43]. The objective of that research is the incorporation of TiO2 and montmorillonite clay (MMT) nanoparticles using different percentages into a synthetic polyamide 6 (PA6) to obtain different nanocomposites. The four adsorbents, MMT, PA6, and MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites were used to attain the optimum U(VI) adsorption parameters for sulfate solutions and their applications for uranium adsorption from EL Sela leach liquor.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and characterization methods
sections.text:
Tetraisopropyl orthotitanate (TIPT) purchased from Merck, Germany. Methanol, Ethanol (absolute AR, 99.9 %), hydrogen peroxide, and n-hexane (AR grade) purchased from SD-fine Chemicals Co. ε-Caprolactam, and phthalic acid obtained from Across Organics Co., Belgium.
Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) (Optima 2100DV, Perkin Elmer) was used to determine uranium ions, the chemical constituents of G. El Sela sample, and its prepared leach
solution as well as the ingredients of the obtained uranium concentrate. X-ray diffraction (XRD) model was reported by a Philips (PW3710), including a diffractometer position (PW 1775), Cu‒target tube, and scintillation counter, for specimens that were irradiated and examined in 2θ range 2 and 80◦. An environmental scan electron microscope (SEM-EDX), Philips XL 30, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) JEOL-2100, Japan, were used to examine the morphological structures of the prepared adsorbents. The Brunauer did the surface area evaluation–Emmett–Teller (BET) Quantachrome Nova - Data Acquisition and Conversion for NOVA instruments, Quantachrome Instruments (USA) version 11.03. The thermal stabilities of the studied solid adsorbents were evaluated by the Thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA) of TA Instruments (STD Q600, USA). FTIR (Shimadzu IR) was controlled by IR resolution, and the software was employed using the KBr tablet method to evaluate the functional groups of all solid samples.

sections.heading: 2.2. Polyamide 6 synthesis
sections.text: Polyamide 6 was manufactured using the ring-opening polycondensation of ε-caprolactam (Fig. 1). First of all, ε-caprolactam (5000 g) was melted at 80− 100 ◦C during 0.5 h under nitrogen flow. Distilled water (150 mL) and phthalic acid (14 g)) as plasticizers were applied to the closed reactor under nitrogen flow, and the temperature was set to 260 ◦C. The pressure inside the closed reactor was set to 4 bar by nitrogen feed. At these conditions, the pressure was increased during the progress of the reaction system to a level of 6 bars. After the reaction time of 4 h (pre-condensation phase), the pressure was released slowly, and water was extracted. In order to eliminate the water, a completely high vacuum was applied. The temperature was set to 280 ◦C. The melt was solidified by removing the strand through an ice bath. Directly, after the solidification, the strand was cut and extracted in a water bath for 2 h at 80 ◦C and then dried. The general procedure was sketched in Fig. 2.

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of nano-TiO2
sections.text: Synthesis of TiO2 nanoparticles was made via the sol-gel method, 2.84 mL TIPT was dissolved in a mixture of 0.5 mL methanol and 5 mL ethanol with molar ratio (1:1:10), and it was refluxed at 60 ◦C for 6 h. After that, 30 mL of distilled H2O was added dropwise to the hot solution at 60 ◦C under continuous stirring condition. The precipitate was separated with filtration and was washed three times with hot water. The obtained white precipitate was dried at 130 ◦C in the oven for 12 h, and it was ground to a fine powder. This powder was subjected to calcination for ten hours at 550 ◦C inside a muffle furnace. Finally, the white crystalline powder of nano-TiO2 was obtained [44].

sections.heading: 2.4. Preparation of nano-montmorillonite
sections.text:
Nano-montmorillonite (MMT) was prepared by the suspension of commercial montmorillonite (2.5 g) in deionized H2O (250 mL). The mixture was agitated for 1 h and heated to 75 ◦C to achieve the suspension solution. Cetyl ammonium bromide (5 g) was dissolved in deionized H2O (50 mL), and it was added by a dropwise to the suspension mixture. The solution pH value was adjusted to 6.7 ± 0.1 by sodium carbonate/acetic acid buffer with constant stirring for four hours. A white precipitate was separated and washed with deionized

sections.heading: 2.5. Preparation of MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites
sections.text: Prior to extrusion, inorganic nanosized (MMT clay or TiO2) particles and PA6 were dried at 80 ◦C in a vacuum oven for 24 h to minimize the effect of moisture and were kept in sealed desiccators. After drying, MMT/PA6 and TiO2/ PA6 hybrids were prepared by a melt compounding system using HAAKE twin-screw extruder by a set of 90 rpm rotary speed using different amounts of MMT and TiO2 (0.5–2 %). The temperature system of the barrel fixed at 250 ◦C – 255 ◦C from a hopper to a die. Eventually, melt strands were cooled inside a water-bath. The formed composites were pelletized by cutting device. For comparison, pure PA6 was also extruded into twin screw extruder at the same process condition.

sections.heading: 2.6. Adsorption studies
sections.text:
For the uranium (VI) adsorption and purification from sulfate solution, several experiments were conducted to get the optimum settings of the relevant parameters, which were pH, initial concentration, time, and temperature. All the operations were completed in duplicate. The adsorption experiments were employed by mixing the prepared adsorbents individually (50 mg) with 25 mL of 300 mg/L U(VI) in 100 mL flasks at the mechanical shaker at 60 min at room temperature. The pH value was studied at pH range 1–6, and it was adjusted using 1 M NaOH or 1 M H2SO4 solutions. Various contact time (5–60 min), different initial uranium ions concentration (125− 1000 mg/L), and different temperatures (25− 50 ◦C) were also studied.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. XRD analysis
sections.text:
Fig. S1 in the supporting information displays XRD patterns of the PA6, nano-TiO2, MMT, and TiO2/PA6, and MMT/PA6 nanocomposites. The XRD pattern of the PA6 has diffraction peaks which appear at 2θ =
18◦, 20◦, 24◦, and 30◦ [46]. From the nano-TiO2 spectrum, the results confirmed that anatase is existed due to the finding of intense diffraction bands at 2θ values and crystal planes of 25.25◦ (101), 37.80◦ (004), 38.50◦ (112), 48.05◦ (200), 53.9◦ (105), 55.05◦ (211), 62.65◦ (204), 68.85◦ (116), 70.30◦ (220), 75.05◦ (215), and 76.10◦ (301), and also diffraction peak at 2θ value of 36.00◦ could be well recognized to (101) reflection of rutile phase [47,48]. The average particle size estimated by the Scherrer’s formula. The average particle size of TiO2 calculated to be 15 nm. However, the XRD form of the MMT showed an intense peak at 2θ = 7.16◦, corresponding to the crystal plane (001) of 12.5 ̊A [49]. The Scherrer equation also estimated the MMT particle size at 25 nm.
On the other side, three peaks exist in the MMT/PA6 spectrum. One sharp peak at 2θ = 7.25◦ shows the MMT layer, and another sharp peak at 2θ = 18◦ shows an increase in the PA6 layer. Hence, polymer entered into the interlayer spaces, and MMT/PA6 structure was formed. Also, another peak at 2θ = 20.8◦ showed some layer of MMT, and it indicated that the intercalated structure was formed. However, at nano-TiO2/PA6, a sharp peak at 2θ = 25.55◦ showed the attendance of nano-TiO2, and it indicated that nano-TiO2 dispersed in PA6 polymer. Hence, it concluded that MMT and nano-TiO2 provided the proper chelation and dispersion at the preparation of PA6 through interfacial polycondensation.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. SEM analysis
sections.text:
The morphology of TiO2 presented in Fig. S2, it was observed that the nano-TiO2 was fine particles through a particular character, and the average particle diameter of TiO2 was approximately less than 16 nm, which was more useful to form a composite with the PA6 matrix [48]. The surface variation was efficient to enhance the distribution of TiO2 in the PA6 form, which performed a vital role in uranium adsorption from sulfate solution on TiO2/PA6 adsorbent (Fig. S2), the particles aggregation and bright spots on the TiO2/PA6 surface represented the uranium ions adsorption.
Furthermore, Fig. S2 showed images of MMT and MMT/PA6 nanocomposite. In the MMT/PA6 image, a small aggregate of about 39 nm in size together with few large aggregates were observed, the presence of these aggregates indicated the combining of MMT particles inside the polymer matrix. The MMT/PA6/U image found the irregular shape and bright spots due to the U(VI) existence on the MMT/PA6 surface. The SEM images indicated that the nano-TiO2 and MMT were homogenously intercalated in the interlayer of PA6. The obtained results, the polymer nanocomposites adsorbents produced.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. EDX analysis
sections.text:
The semi-quantitative analysis of nano-TiO2, PA6, MMT, MMT/PA6, MMT/PA6/U, TiO2/PA6, and TiO2/PA6/U was attained by EDX analysis (Fig. S3). The chemical composition of nano-TiO2 presented only Ti and O peaks while PA6 form offered C and O peaks. It means that nano-TiO2 and PA6 are highly purified. The MMT spectrum showed that the elemental constitutions contained Si, Al, O, Mg, Ca, Fe, Cl, Ni, and Cu peaks, but in MMT/PA6 spectrum exhibited the grouping peaks between MMT and PA6 composite, in addition to TiO2/PA6 spectrum presented combination peaks of TiO2 and PA6 composite. sections.heading: 3.1.4. TEM analysis
sections.text:
The adsorbent’s morphological features were also characterized by TEM. Fig. S4 showed that the adsorbents were distributed homogeneously, and they could be described as homogeneous dispersion, while the particulates dispersed as individual particles. Montmorillonite nanoparticles were aggregated due to the attendance of hydroxide groups. The MMT particles had nano-size particles (<30 nm). Additionally, the MMT/PA6 composite (average diameter 30–40 nm) shows different areas: the bright areas signified nanoparticles of MMT and introduced into the dark particles of the PA6. In the other direction, the TiO2 nanoparticles tended to aggregate due to the attendance of hydrogen bonds. The TiO2 nanoparticles were still at the nano-size level (<20 nm).
Moreover, the TiO2/PA6 structure (average diameter 25–35 nm) showed that the bright areas represented the small particles of TiO2 with an average diameter of 10− 20 nm. Besides, the dark particles of the organic polymer (PA6) due to the different electron- attractive abilities (viz., the electron binding capability of TiO2 was further than the polymer shell). Therefore, the cores could be identified as the bright region related to the coverage area.

sections.heading: 3.1.5. BET analysis
sections.text: Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) explained the adsorption of nitrogen molecules on the solid surface and served as the origin for the vital analytical method for measuring of the surface area, average pore volume, and average pore size of the prepared nano-materials. As exposed in Table 1, the pore size, surface area, and also pore volume of PA6 are 18.51 nm, 29.12 m2/g, and 0.086 cc/g, respectively. A change of physical structure of PA6 was observed due to the formation of TiO2/ PA6 and MMT/PA6 nano-composites. Because of that, the high values of the pore size, and surface area, of TiO2 and MMT. Therefore, the values of pore size and surface area for TiO2/PA6 and MMT/PA6 are higher than the PA6. From the data in Table 1, it could be attributed that the individual nano-TiO2 and MMT decorated PA6 pores. The porosity and surface area of the addition of nano-TiO2 and MMT improved the PA6 to adsorb uranium ions.

sections.heading: 3.1.6. Thermal analysis
sections.text:
Thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA) was utilized to explain the thermal stabilities of nano-TiO2, PA6 polymer, MMT, TiO2/PA6, MMT/ PA6, U-loaded TiO2/PA6, and MMT/PA6/U at 10 ◦C/min heat rate in the range 0–900 ◦C under N2 atmosphere (Fig. S5). TGA has demonstrated to be a suitable method to investigate the thermal stability of nanocomposites. The curve nano-TiO2 provided two main mass losses within the TGA experiment. The first mass loss occurred at about 107 ◦C due to the water evaporation. The second mass loss occurred at 107–342 ◦C, which is due to the volatilization and combustion of organic species [48]. Moreover, it was distinguished that the montmorillonite TGA showed three mass loss phases in between 25–100 ◦C, and at 135.4 ◦C
besides at 636.5 ◦C (Fig. S5). These mass loss phases attributed to desorption of water from the clay, dehydration of the hydrated cation in the interlayer, and the dehydroxylation of the montmorillonite, respectively [49]. Furthermore, polyamide 6 was stable up to 347 ◦C. The decomposition of polyamide PA6 occurred in the range of 347− 514 ◦C. PA6 left a small amount of residue. The addition of 1.5 % of MMT or TiO2 on PA6 slightly increased the thermal stabilities of two nanocomposites and did significantly change the thermal analysis of the system [50]. The curves of TiO2/PA6/U and MMT/PA6/U indicated that the TiO2/PA6/U and MMT/PA6/U started to disintegrate at 220 ◦C, giving 5 % mass loss giving high thermal stability. The initial mass loss in all samples might attribute to the dehydration of the coordinated water. In the case of TiO2/PA6/U, and MMT/PA6/U, the degradation was decreased at comparing with TiO2/PA6, and MMT/PA6 after 530 ◦C, it may transpire because of the adsorbed uranium on the two adsorbents.

sections.heading: 3.1.7. FTIR analysis
sections.text:
FTIR spectra used in this study as a qualitative measurement to analyze the chemical structures of PA6, MMT, TiO2, MMT/PA6, TiO2/ PA6, MMT/PA6/U, and TiO2/PA6/U (Fig. S6). At the PA6 spectrum, the band at 3291 cm− 1 belonged to the NH– stretching bond. The bands at 3075 cm− 1 and 1633 cm− 1 indicated CH– stretching band and C–O stretching, respectively. CN– stretching bands gave two bands at 1537 and 1257 cm− 1 [51]. The spectrum of MMT showed that peak at 3273 cm–1 indicated to Si–OH bands. The band at 1604 cm–1 exhibited the existence of structural water within the montmorillonite matrix. The three bands at 1199, 1001, and 758 cm–1 attributed to SiO– stretching vibrations designating the appearance of silicate. Bands at 602 and 469 cm–1 corresponded to Al–OSi and SiOS–––i bending bands [49]. At the nano-TiO2 spectrum, the band at 3388 cm− 1 described to the stretching band of the surface hydroxyl group, and the band at 1648 cm− 1 matched to the vibration of –OH group on the nano-TiO2 surface. The wide-band to the extent of 500–790 cm− 1 matched to TiOT––i bands [48].
The MMT/PA6 spectrum showed the characteristic band for the C–O group around 1633 cm− 1, and the two stretching bands of CN– at 1538, and 1258 cm− 1 of PA6. The weak bands of SiO– shifted to 1160, and 955 cm–1. Bands at 601 and 482 cm–1 corresponds to Al–OSi and SiOS–––i bending peaks. It was proved that MMT effectively modified the PA6. TiO2/PA6 spectrum displayed the specific band for the C–O group at 1633 cm− 1, and the two stretching bands of CN– at 1538 and 1259 cm− 1 of PA6. The new broadband around 520–800 cm− 1 ascribed to the TiOT––i band. It was evidenced that nano-TiO2 successfully modified the PA6. After U(VI) adsorption, the spectrum of MMT/PA6/U and TiO2/PA6/U showed a new band at 974 cm− 1 for UO– [52]. Moreover, the stretching bands for the MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 were also shifted to redshift with 10− 15 cm− 1, which might be due to the U (VI) adsorption on MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 adsorbents.

sections.heading: 3.2. Adsorption comprehension
sections.text: The uranium adsorption applied on MMT, PA6, and MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites from the G. El Sela leach solution. Several sets of equilibrium experiments were done upon uranium adsorption efficiency to optimize the pH value, contact time, initial uranium ions concentration, and temperature. The pH value was studied at pH range 1–6, and it was adjusted using 1 M NaOH or 1 M H2SO4 solutions. Various contact time (5–60 min), different initial uranium ions concentration (125− 1000 mg/L), and different temperatures (25− 50 ◦C) were also studied.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Solution pH
sections.text:
The pH influence on the uranium (VI) adsorption onto 50 mg of individual MMT, and PA6, MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites were studied in different pH values from 1 to 6 at fixed experimental

Journal of Environmental Chemical Engineering 8 (2020) 104427
conditions of 25 mL solution assaying 300 mg/L of uranium ions for 60 min contact time at 25 ◦C (Fig. 3). From the gained data, the uranium uptake capacities of MMT, PA6, and MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites (qe) increased from 16.0, 3.0, 24.0 and 10.0–93.0, 21.0, 134.0, and 125.0 mg/g, respectively with increasing the pH value from 1.0 to 4.5. Subsequently, the increase of the pH up to 6 admitted to a decline of uranium uptake capacity to 40.0, 8.0, 55.0, and 47.0 mg/g, respectively. Thus, the maximum U(VI) uptake capacity attained at solution pH 4.5.
At pH < 4.5, the MMT, PA6, MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 surfaces would protonate with hydrogen ions, whereas the silanol and aluminol groups of MMT were extra protonated, and the Ti–OH group of nanoTiO2, and amino and carbonyl groups of PA6 were also protonated. Besides, the existence of bisulfate ions (HSO4− ) were readily adsorbed on the protonated active sites because bisulfate ions had the smallest size. The electrostatic effect between the protonated active sites and the complex anionic species of uranium (UO2(SO4)22- and UO2(SO4)34− ) are slightly adsorbed due to the bisulfate ions (HSO4− ) that competed with the uranium anionic complex species.
In the sequence at pH 4.5, uranium existed in hydrolyzed forms, and the following cationic species have identified UO22+, [(UO2)2(OH)2]2+ dimer, [(UO2)3(OH)5]+ trimer. Whereas the hydrogen ions on the active sites of the montmorillonite and TiO2 liberated and the active sites tended to gain the negative charges as Si–O− , AlO–− and TiO–− sites. In other descriptions, each active site had a substantial negative net charge because of the release of hydrogen cation of the hydroxyl group. Thus, it performed to attract electrostatically any positive ions. This adsorption behavior could be inductive of inner-sphere complexation or adsorption to sites possessing negative charge [52]. On the opposite aspect, the adsorption uptake at pH < 4.5 was gradually decreased as an outcome of the formation of uranyl hydroxide species [UO2(OH)2, UO2(OH)3− , UO2(OH)42-, (UO2)3(OH)7− , (UO2)3(OH)82− and (UO2)3(OH)115− [30] which were gradually precipitated. Therefore, it was not possible to perform the pH effect behind 6.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Contact time and adsorption kinetics
sections.text:
The adsorption time is the main aspect of uranium uptake adsorption. This aspect was studied through several experiments that were employed by 50 mg of individual MMT, PA6, MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 adsorbents at different contact times (5–60 min) while the other experimental parameters were constant. As presented in Fig. 4, the uranium uptake capacities of the MMT, PA6, MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 increased to 93.0, 21.0, 134.0, and 125.0 mg/g with increasing contact time until 30 min, respectively and by increasing time up to 60 min, there was no noticeable effect on the uranium ions uptake. Hence, 30 min contact was the equilibrium time, and it was used for further optimizing conditions for uranium adsorption.

sections.text:

The results in Fig. 7 exposed that as the initial concentrations increased, it was led to increasing the uranium uptake that reached a maximum loading at 750 mg/L uranium concentration. After that, the overloaded uranium kept constant. It represents that the studied adsorbents reached the maximum packing capacity (saturation capacity), because of the mobility of UO22+ in the solutions are the highest and the whole active sites of the adsorbents saturated and blocked with uranyl ions.
Several isotherm equations are used for the equilibrium modeling of adsorption systems. Among these, two are commonly used and applied for this study, the Freundlich and Langmuir isotherms. The Freundlich isotherm model is a special case applied to non-ideal sorption onto heterogeneous surfaces and also to multilayer sorption, suggesting that binding sites are not equivalent [39]. The adsorption isotherm data were analyzed by the Freundlich isotherm model, which in its linearized form is:

The Langmuir model refers to homogeneous adsorption, which assumes that all active sites possess a similar affinity to the adsorbate with a uniformly saturated monolayer, and it has equivalent energies with no interaction between adsorbate molecules even on adjacent sites [56]. sections.text: The effect of Fe3+, Ce4+, Th4+, SO42− , NO3-, and Cl- ions (300 mg/L) on the uranium uptake capacities executed at MMT, PA6, and MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites under all other experimental factors fixed on the above conditions. sections.heading: 3.3. Mechanism of adsorption
sections.text:
Spectroscopic evidence collected by SEM, EDX, and FTIR before and after adsorption was provided invaluable information that helped in the
understanding of the adsorption mechanism of U(VI) on MMT, PA6, MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 adsorbents. From the SEM of TiO2/PA6/U and MMT/PA6/U (Fig. S2), the bright spots on their surfaces represented the uranium ions adsorption. After uranium ions adsorption on the two adsorbents (MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6), it could be observed clearly from their EDX spectra (Fig. S3) the presence of uranium peaks, confirming the adsorption of uranium ions. A comparison of the FTIR spectra of MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites before and after U (VI) loading (Fig. S6) exhibited that a new peak appeared at 974 cm− 1, which corresponds to U–O [52]. Moreover, the stretching bands for the MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 were also shifted to redshift with 10− 15 cm− 1. It might be due to the U(VI) adsorption on the adsorbents.
Further demonstration of the adsorption mechanism was manifested by the effect of pH on U(VI) adsorption (Fig. 3). The pH-dependent trend implies that the mechanism of U(VI) binding may be through the deprotonation of functional groups of adsorbents. Optimum pH was 4.5, at which cationic species identified are UO22+, [(UO2)2(OH)2]2+ dimer, and [(UO2)3(OH)5]+ trimer. At pH 4.5, the active sites on adsorbents surfaces were tended to gain the negative charges such as Si–O− , AlO–− , TiO–− , CO–− , and COO––− sites that attract electrostatically any positive ions. These variations with pH also tend to confirm the involvement of weak acid groups in the sorption process through cation exchange mechanisms [52].
The kinetics suggested that the adsorption can be fitted more appropriately by the PSO kinetic model, and the PSO adsorption mechanism is predominant, which indicating saturated adsorption sites and the adsorption was dominated by chemisorption. From isotherm studies, the Langmuir model shows an excellent fit for the experimental data. It may be due to homogeneous distribution of active sites on MMT/ PA6, and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites surfaces and so the main adsorption form of U(VI) was a single layer of adsorption. The adsorption process was exothermic and spontaneous, as deduced from thermodynamics data (Table 5).
As mentioned above, U(VI) had tendencies to form complexes with the O and N containing functional groups within the adsorbents used. According to the above analysis, the schematic visualization of the possible adsorption mechanisms of the U(VI) onto the surface of TiO2/ PA6, and MMT/PA6 nanocomposites were proposed and shown in Figs. 13, 14, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.4. Elution investigations
sections.text:
The elution of uranium ions that loaded on the MMT, PA6, MMT/ PA6, and TiO2/PA6 was studied using different concentrations of H2SO4,
M.F. Cheira et al.
Journal of Environmental Chemical Engineering 8 (2020) 104427
HNO3, HCl, and Na2CO3 ranging from 0.05 to 0.30 M. Desorption study was indeed applied for the regeneration of the prepared adsorbents. It also is the critical factor to diminish the cost of the purification of uranium ions. Several experiments were managed by agitating 2 g of uranium ions loaded adsorbents with 40 mL of individual eluting solutions, 150 rpm stirring speed at room temperature for 30 min contact time. Fig. S7 indicated that the 0.25 M nitric acid eluted almost uranium ions for the loaded adsorbents. Finally, 0.25 M HNO3 is the best concentration for regeneration and reusability of MMT, PA6, MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 after seven cycles.

sections.heading: 3.5. Uranium recovery
sections.text:
The studied representative granitic sample was collected from the El Sela area, South Eastern, Egypt. It was applied for uranium leaching by appropriate conditions that give the best leaching efficiency (93.75 % uranium(VI)) with the least dissolution of impurities [58]. The prepared leach liquor was obtained from 1 kg of the properly El Sela ore material (100-149 μm) with 4 L of sulfuric acid (150 mg/L) and (NH4)2SO4 (150 mg/L) mixture, contact time (6 h), stirring speed (200 rpm), and ambient temperature. The controlled leach liquor had pH 1.95, and the U(VI) concentration assessed 300 mg/L. The El Sela ore material and its
M.F. Cheira et al.
Journal of Environmental Chemical Engineering 8 (2020) 104427
leach solution were analyzed by the appropriate procedures (Table 6). Uranium adsorption was applied from 4 L of leach solution that has 300 mg/L of uranium ions and some interfering ions, using 10 g of MMT/PA6 or TiO2/PA6 under pH 4.5, and 30 min contact time. According to the previous results, the uranium(VI) uptake on the MMT/ PA6 or TiO2/PA6 was 134.0 or 125 mg U/g adsorbent, respectively. Finally, the whole uranium ions in the El Sela leach solution were captured on the 10 g of MMT/PA6 or TiO2/PA6 adsorbents (1.2 g uranium ions/10 g adsorbent).
The desorption of U(VI) from MMT/PA6/U or TiO2/PA6/U) was carried out by agitating 0.2 L of 0.25 M nitric acid for 30 min contact time at room temperature. The uranium ions in the eluting solution (UO2(NO3)2) was analyzed, and the uranium concentration was assessed (5.95 g/L). The uranium ions were precipitated from the eluting solution after the evaporation process to a 50 mL solution. The precipitation process was carried out via the dropwise addition of 50 % H2O2 after adjusting the solution pH to 2 by 10 % ammonium hydroxide to precipitate uranium ions as UO4.xH2O (1.79 g), which was dried at 110 ◦C. The final product was uranium peroxide hydrate (1.55 g).
X-ray diffraction of the final product showed that uranium was precipitated as peroxide hydrate that has the chemical formula UO4∙2H2O and UO4∙4H2O (Fig. S8) [59,60]. The XRF analysis indicated that the product was composed of uranium and some associated metal ions distinct peaks (Fig. S9). Moreover, it was quantitatively analyzed by the suitable technique (ICP-OES) to identify some chemical constituents that are 67.44 % U(VI), 0.01 % Ti(IV), 0.008 % V(V), 0.31 % Y(III), 0.23 % La(III), and 0.02 % Cd(II). Finally, the achieved data demonstrated that uranium peroxide hydrate evaluated 94.29 %.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
MMT, TiO2, PA6, MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 adsorbents were successfully synthesized and characterized by XRD, SEM, EDX, TEM, TGA, and FTIR. The prepared four adsorbents were utilized to adsorb uranium ions from sulfate solution. The maximum uranium uptake on MMT, PA6, MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 are 93.0, 21.0, 134.0, and 125.0 mg/g at pH 4.5, for 30 min contact time, at ambient temperature. From the kinetic data, uranium adsorption was suited well via pseudo-second-order model and adsorption isotherm data more suitably fitted the Langmuir model.
Likewise, the negative ΔH◦ values indicated the exothermic adsorption reaction, and negative ΔS◦ values showed random performance for U(VI) adsorption, but negative ΔG◦ values directed spontaneous U(VI) adsorption. The maximum uptake of U(VI) on MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites were higher than that of pure PA6, due to the improved porosity and higher surface area for MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 in comparison to PA6. Tentative adsorption mechanisms were suggested that revealed ion-exchange and electrostatic interaction between MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites and uranium ions. The maximum U(VI) desorption from the loaded four adsorbents was performed using 0.25 M HNO3. The uranium ions adsorption-desorption method onto the MMT, PA6, MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 adsorbents after seven successive cycles,
which was designated the excellent adsorption stability of all adsorbents. The optimum adsorption conditions applied to the El Sela leach solution for uranium recovery as uranium peroxide that was assessed 94.29 %. Finally, the MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites would be effective and promising adsorbents for U(VI) adsorption from aqueous solutions.

metadata.abstractText: The polyamide-based nanocomposites were formed via inorganic nanosized (montmorillonite clay MMT, or TiO2) particles that incorporated inside a polyamide 6 (PA6) matrix. Moreover, the MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites were prepared by simple dissolution methods. Morphology of the gained nanocomposites was studied by SEM, EDX, TEM, FTIR, and XRD techniques. Batch adsorption was fulfilled to determine the uptake capacities of U(VI) (93.0, 21.0, 134.0, and 125.0 mg/g) on the MMT, PA6, and MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites, respectively from sulfate solution in the pH 4.5, 30 min contact time at room temperature. The adsorption-desorption recycling was indicated that U(VI) adsorption has excellent stability and selectivity after seven cycles by 0.25 M HNO3 eluant. The kinetic data of uranium adsorption on MMT, PA6, and MMT/PA6 and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites were suited well to a pseudo-second-order mechanism, and the Langmuir isotherm followed the equilibrium adsorption experiments. The tentative mechanism of the adsorption of U(VI) on adsorbents was proposed. Finally, the optimum adsorption conditions for MMT/PA6, and TiO2/PA6 nanocomposites were applied for U(VI) recovery from the El-Sela sulfate leach solution.
